Systems.Name: Propulsion
Systems.Description: Warp, impulse, maneuvering thrusters, inertial management.
Systems.SidebarText:
Warp, impulse, maneuvering thrusters, inertial management.

Featured: Warp drive

Notes:
• Warp operation depends on stable warp field geometry; asymmetry or coil imbalance can force a shutdown.
• High warp output competes with other ship systems for power; emergency routing is common during combat or damage control.
• Warp travel can be unsafe or impossible in certain spatial anomalies, dense fields, or subspace‑distorted regions.

Systems.Name: Shipboard Weapons
Systems.Description: Phasers, torpedoes, and integrated tactical fire-control for starship combat.
Systems.SidebarText: Shipboard weapons cover the standard tools of starship combat: directed‑energy emitters, projectile ordnance, and the targeting and firing systems that tie them together. In most eras, Starfleet’s baseline loadout is phasers plus torpedoes, with earlier NX‑era ships relying on phase cannons and spatial torpedoes before later upgrades.

Technologies.Name: Impulse drive
Technologies.Summary:
Impulse drive is the standard sublight propulsion mode used by starships for routine travel within a star system, close‑range navigation, docking approaches, formation flight, and tactical maneuvering. In practice, it’s the ship’s everyday “under normal space” engine: the setting you hear most often on the bridge—one‑quarter impulse, half impulse, or full impulse—when warp is unnecessary, unsafe, or simply the wrong tool.

On screen, impulse is consistently framed as a power‑regulated propulsion system integrated into the ship’s overall energy management. Captains call for changes in *impulse power* as readily as they call for shields or phasers, and engineering treats impulse as something that can be surged, rerouted, repaired, shut down, or pushed beyond safe limits in emergencies.

Sections.What impulse drive is:
Impulse drive (often referred to as the ship’s impulse engines) provides sustained sublight thrust. It is used whenever a ship needs precise, controllable acceleration without engaging warp—leaving drydock, maneuvering in orbit, holding station, closing to transport range, or fighting at close quarters.

Impulse is also an operational concept: bridge orders like “impulse power at your discretion,” “reduce impulse power,” or “full impulse” are treated as standardized shorthand for how hard the ship should push its sublight engines under current conditions.
Sections.Impulse power and shipwide energy manage:
Impulse is presented as a major consumer of a ship’s power budget. Dialogue frequently treats impulse output as something that can be raised, lowered, restored, or lost—sometimes independently of other systems. When a ship is damaged, crews may fight to get *impulse power* back online, reroute conduits, or manually restore the engine feed so the ship can maneuver or escape.

That framing matters for your database: impulse isn’t just “go fast.” In many stories, it’s the difference between being able to change position, hold orbit, break a tractor lock, or avoid impact—especially when warp is unavailable.
Sections.Command language and operating modes:
Impulse is commonly expressed as a fraction of maximum (“one‑quarter impulse,” “half impulse,” “full impulse”). The shows don’t lock this to a single universal velocity; instead, it behaves like a bridge‑level throttle setting that accounts for ship class, mass, power availability, and safety constraints.

Two related concepts show up repeatedly:
• **Reverse impulse** — the ship applies impulse thrust in reverse for braking, backing off, or holding position.
• **Impulse at discretion** — the pilot or helmsman selects a safe output appropriate to the situation without needing a specific number.
Sections.Use cases across the franchise:
Impulse drive dominates day‑to‑day operations. It’s the mode for in‑system travel and close‑range work: leaving spacedock, approaching a planet, rendezvousing with another vessel, or executing delicate maneuvers where warp fields would be hazardous.

It also shows up in “time pressure” situations: ships run at impulse inside systems to intercept threats or reach a destination quickly while still obeying whatever limits apply to warp travel in that environment.
Sections.Tactical significance:
Most starship engagements are depicted at sublight scales: ships circle, exchange fire, line up torpedo shots, and reposition to protect a damaged area of shields. In that context, impulse performance is effectively the ship’s tactical mobility—how quickly it can bring weapons to bear, evade an attack run, or hold a defensive formation.

Damage to impulse is therefore a serious tactical blow. When impulse drops offline, a ship can become a drifting target, unable to maintain distance or change heading effectively.
Sections.Failure modes, stress, and emergency beh:
Impulse engines are often portrayed as temperamental under damage or extreme demand: they can surge, cut out, overheat, or require emergency handling. Stories treat “pushing impulse” as something that can be risky—either because the engines are already compromised or because the ship is operating at the edge of what its structure and systems can safely support.

In the most extreme cases, impulse operation is linked to catastrophic outcomes: a damaged ship may risk blowing its impulse engines, or an engineering team may attempt to overload the system as part of a desperate plan.
Sections.Visual identity and ship design cues:
Impulse drive is frequently represented visually by paired impulse engine ports or grilles on the aft portion of a ship’s main hull. These are distinct from warp nacelles and are treated as the visible “sublight engines.”

Even when the exact geometry varies by era and class, the storytelling function is consistent: the impulse assembly signals sublight thrust and provides a recognizable cue for whether the ship is maneuvering under impulse rather than at warp.
Sections.Relationship to warp, thrusters, and ine:
Impulse sits in a family of ship handling systems. Thrusters handle fine translation and attitude changes; impulse provides sustained thrust for travel and combat maneuvers; warp handles interstellar transit. In practice, these systems interlock—particularly with inertial management—because the ship must remain habitable and controllable under acceleration.

This is why impulse is repeatedly treated as more than a toggle: it’s a major operational mode that affects navigation, tactics, and the ship’s ability to function when other propulsion options are restricted.

Technologies.Name: Thrusters
Technologies.Summary:
Thrusters are the ship’s low‑power reaction control devices: small engine outlets distributed around the hull that provide precise attitude and translation control. They’re used when impulse is too blunt or too risky—docking, station‑keeping, slow backing maneuvers, close formation work, and careful alignment in tight spaces.

Star Trek treats thrusters as a separate layer of propulsion that sits underneath impulse and warp. They don’t make a ship “fast” on their own, but they make it controllable—especially at low velocity, in confined areas, or when the main engines are unavailable.

Sections.What thrusters do:
Thrusters (often referred to as maneuvering thrusters, maneuvering jets, or reaction control thrusters) provide fine control over a ship’s motion: tiny changes in heading, gentle translational movement, controlled rotation about an axis, and the ability to hold position relative to another object.

They’re most often invoked when a ship needs to move carefully—leaving spacedock, lining up with a docking port, holding station near a platform or debris field, or creeping away from danger without the shove of impulse.
Sections.Reaction control and station‑keeping:
The franchise frequently frames thrusters as the tool for station‑keeping—maintaining a fixed position relative to another object by continuously making small corrections. This is the practical difference between thrusters and impulse: impulse is great for sustained travel and larger acceleration, but station‑keeping is about micro‑maneuvers repeated constantly.

Thrusters also provide the slow, deliberate motion you see during docking, undocking, and careful alignment maneuvers, where even small errors can be dangerous.
Sections.Maneuvering thrusters vs. acceleration t:
On screen and in technical labeling, thrusters show up in more than one role. The most common are maneuvering thrusters—built for control, not speed. Some references also distinguish acceleration thrusters, which can add speed but still live below impulse in both power and purpose.

For Tec‑Trek, it’s useful to treat Thrusters as the umbrella entry, with maneuvering thrusters as the primary subtype you’ll actually see in day‑to‑day ship handling.
Sections.How crews interact with them:
Thrusters are usually run through flight control systems, but the franchise also acknowledges manual thruster control—where a control mode or panel can be used to command thrusters directly. That matters for storytelling: if main power is compromised, if automation is unreliable, or if the ship needs an unusually delicate or deliberate move, thruster control becomes a named action.

Thruster control is also treated as something that can be lost when power fails—reinforcing that thrusters are part of the ship’s broader power and control infrastructure.
Sections.Failure modes and why they matter:
Because thrusters are the precision layer, losing them often turns a manageable situation into a crisis. When a ship can’t back off slowly, can’t rotate away from danger, or can’t hold a stable attitude, even having impulse available may not solve the immediate problem—especially in a confined environment or near a hazard.

Stories use thruster failures to raise the stakes in slow-motion scenarios: creeping too close to an object, losing control during delicate docking, or being unable to maintain safe alignment.
Sections.Where they fit in the propulsion stack:
A useful way to think about propulsion in Star Trek is as a stack of operating layers:

• Thrusters: precision control and low‑velocity motion (attitude, translation, station‑keeping)
• Impulse: standard sublight travel and combat maneuvering at scale
• Warp: field‑based interstellar travel

Thrusters therefore belong in Propulsion even though they aren’t the main engines. They’re the ship’s fine-handling muscles—the part you miss immediately when it’s gone.

Technologies.Name: Warp drive
Technologies.Summary:
Warp drive is the core faster‑than‑light propulsion technology used by most interstellar powers in Star Trek. Rather than treating speed as simple acceleration through normal space, warp travel is framed as controlled field generation: a ship produces a shaped warp field—often described as a subspace bubble—that allows sustained superluminal transit between stars.

Because warp is an operating mode rather than a single component, a complete “warp drive” entry naturally spans the ship’s power reactor (the warp core and its matter/antimatter reaction system), distribution hardware (plasma/EPS pathways), and the field projectors (warp coils in the nacelles) that form and stabilize the warp field.

Sections.What warp drive is:
Warp drive (sometimes called a warp engine) enables faster‑than‑light travel by generating warp fields around a vessel. The field is described as a subspace‑related effect that envelops the ship, allowing interstellar distances to be crossed in practical time. On the bridge, warp performance is communicated using warp factors (“warp six,” “warp 9.2”), which function as an operational shorthand for the field settings required to achieve a given effective velocity.

Across eras, the franchise keeps the same recognizable idea—warp fields, warp factors, nacelles, and a warp core—while letting specific details vary by ship class and period.
Sections.Warp field and the subspace bubble:
On-screen dialogue repeatedly treats the warp field as a shaped structure that must remain stable: crews diagnose field asymmetry, harmonics, and other stability problems rather than simply “losing speed.” The common implication is that the ship is riding inside a controlled field configuration (often called a warp bubble or subspace bubble) that permits superluminal transit.

This framing is useful for storytelling because it makes warp travel adjustable and fallible. A ship can be forced out of warp by field instability, interference, or damage to the hardware that generates and regulates the field—without requiring that the entire ship be physically destroyed.
Sections.The warp core and the matter/antimatter:
Federation starships are most often portrayed as powering warp operations with a controlled matter/antimatter reaction in the warp core’s reaction assembly. Matter and antimatter are injected into a central reaction region in a regulated intermix ratio, releasing enormous energy. Dilithium is consistently referenced as a key element in moderating and regulating that reaction so energy can be safely drawn for ship systems.

The warp core is therefore both propulsion-critical and ship-critical: it’s treated as the heart of the vessel’s energy budget, with stability, containment, and shutdown procedures forming a constant part of engineering life.
Sections.Nacelles, warp coils, and field generati:
While the core produces the power and reaction control, the ship’s warp nacelles are repeatedly framed as the field‑generation hardware. Warp coils (field coils) housed in the nacelles are fed by the core’s output—commonly described as plasma routed through conduits—and then used to project and shape the warp field.

This is why nacelles are treated as essential systems: damage to a nacelle, coil assembly, or the plasma feed can produce immediate warp‑field problems even if the core remains intact.
Sections.Warp factors and performance:
Warp speed is expressed as a warp factor. Warp one marks the light‑speed threshold for warp travel, and higher factors represent increasingly greater effective velocities. The franchise is not perfectly consistent about mapping warp factor to a single numeric “times light speed” value, but it is consistently portrayed as non‑linear—small changes near the top end are treated as major jumps in performance and stress.

In practical terms, warp factor is the language the crew uses to communicate intent (“make best speed,” “maximum warp,” “warp nine”) while the computer and engineering systems handle the underlying field geometry, power routing, and safety margins.
Sections.Operations, safeties, and failure modes:
Warp operation is depicted as a balance between power, stability, and structural limits. Common operational themes include rerouting power, balancing flow between nacelles, tuning field harmonics, isolating damaged conduits, and executing emergency shutdowns.

Commonly referenced failure risks include containment loss or a core breach, field collapse due to coil damage or imbalance, and cascading power tradeoffs where maintaining warp conflicts with shields, weapons, or critical life support. These risks keep warp drive grounded as an engineered system with real procedures rather than a purely magical travel button.
Sections.Environmental impact and speed limits:
A notable 24th‑century concern raised on screen is cumulative subspace damage linked to sustained high‑warp travel in certain regions. In response, Starfleet institutes a warp speed restriction (a “speed limit”) with emergency exceptions, emphasizing that warp operation can have systemic consequences beyond an individual ship’s maintenance.

Later stories treat the restriction as temporary or unevenly applied, but the episode establishes an enduring idea: warp drive is powerful enough to create environmental side effects under the right conditions.
Sections.History and development:
Human warp history is anchored by Zefram Cochrane’s first successful warp flight, which becomes a turning point leading directly to first contact with the Vulcans. From there, Starfleet warp systems advance from early, more limited reactors to the mature 23rd‑ and 24th‑century architectures built around high‑output warp cores, nacelle coil systems, and increasingly refined control and safety layers.

Different cultures field different design approaches—some emphasizing stealth, speed, or alternative superluminal methods—so “warp drive” also sits inside a larger family of faster‑than‑light technologies that include transwarp concepts and other specialized propulsion modes.

Technologies.Name: Phase Cannons
Technologies.Summary:
Phase cannons are ship-mounted phase‑modulated directed‑energy cannon weapons used by Starfleet in the mid‑22nd century, most famously as the primary energy weapon of NX‑class ships. They’re positioned as a direct precursor to later phaser technology.

On NX-class ships, phase cannons deploy from retractable turrets and can be set at different yields, making them the NX‑era answer to the flexible beam weapons later ships take for granted.

Sections.What they are: A phase cannon is a phase‑modulated directed‑energy cannon weapon—part of the phase-weapon family that bridges earlier plasma weapons and later phasers. They serve as the ship‑mounted analogue to handheld phase pistols.
Sections.NX‑class implementation: On NX‑class ships, phase cannons are mounted on retractable turrets that extend from the hull and rotate to target. This gives NX‑era ships a visually and mechanically distinct weapons profile compared with later flush-mounted arrays.
Sections.Yield and tactical role: Phase cannons are rated for a maximum output cited in technical descriptions and are shown as configurable in yield. They’re introduced as a primary defensive armament, supplementing early torpedo limitations and providing repeatable directed fire.
Sections.Technology lineage: Phase cannons are explicitly framed as precursors to later phasers. That makes them a natural ‘bridge entry’ in the database: you can connect NX-era weapon development directly into the standard phaser family used later.

Technologies.Name: Phasers
Technologies.Summary:
Phasers are Starfleet’s standard directed‑energy weapon system, used from handheld sidearms up through starship emitters. On ships, phasers are valued for precision, rapid re‑targeting, and controllable output—ranging from warning shots and disabling strikes to sustained fire for hull damage.

Phaser technology grew out of earlier phase‑modulated particle weapons; by later centuries, phaser arrays and banks became the default ship‑to‑ship energy armament.

Sections.What a starship phaser is:
A starship phaser is a ship‑mounted directed‑energy emitter that can deliver focused energy on target as a beam or pulse, depending on the installation and era. Ships commonly distribute emitters across the hull to widen firing arcs and reduce blind spots.

Compared with torpedoes, phasers are the ‘immediate response’ weapon: they’re fast, can be walked across a target, and can be used repeatedly without loading a new round.
Sections.Phaser arrays, banks, and cannons:
Star Trek uses several labels for ship phasers. Phaser banks are grouped emitter installations common in earlier eras, while phaser arrays are long, distributed emitter strips that can fire along their length to provide broad coverage. Some ships mount phaser cannons—heavier forward‑firing systems optimized for punch rather than coverage.

For the database, it’s useful to treat these as variants under one core technology entry, because they share the same basic role: ship‑to‑ship directed‑energy fire.
Sections.Output control and tactical use:
Phasers are routinely portrayed as adjustable in effect and intensity. That flexibility supports ‘damage for purpose’: disabling a subsystem, cutting into a specific area of the hull, or applying sustained pressure against shields.

Phasers are also used as utility tools in some scenarios—cutting, heating, or controlled ablation—though shipboard use is most often framed through tactical fire and target selection.
Sections.Power, firing limits, and heat:
Ship phasers draw from the vessel’s power systems through tactical distribution. Because they can fire repeatedly, the limiting factor tends to be power availability, heat management, and the ship’s ability to keep emitters and control hardware within safe operating limits.

In story terms, this is why battles often include lines about diverting power to phasers, taking emitters offline, or losing phaser control after system damage.
Sections.Relationship to earlier phase technology: Phaser technology is described as being preceded by phase‑modulated particle weapons used in the mid‑22nd century, including ship‑mounted phase cannons. That lineage matters for Tec‑Trek because it ties NX‑era armaments to later Federation standards: phase cannons are a recognizable ancestor rather than an unrelated one‑off.

Technologies.Name: Photon Torpedoes
Technologies.Summary:
Photon torpedoes are warp‑capable tactical matter/antimatter weapons commonly deployed on starships and starbases. They serve as the standard heavy projectile complement to phasers: slower than beams, but capable of delivering concentrated explosive force.

They debut on-screen in TOS and remain a franchise workhorse across eras, with frequent mission‑specific modifications (yield tuning, special payloads, sensor packages, and guidance profiles).

Sections.What makes a photon torpedo different:
Photon torpedoes are physical projectiles with an energetic warhead. Unlike phasers, they deliver damage through a detonation rather than continuous energy application. They’re used when a single strike matters—breaking a target, forcing shields, or delivering a specialized payload.

Torpedoes are also routinely shown as configurable before launch, which is why crews talk about arming, setting yields, and loading special warheads.
Sections.Warp capability and pursuit: A key trait often emphasized is that photon torpedoes can be warp‑capable, allowing engagement across larger tactical envelopes than purely sublight munitions. This supports the classic Star Trek ‘chase and fire’ rhythm—torpedoes remain relevant even when ships are maneuvering fast.
Sections.Launchers, tubes, and firing arcs:
Ships mount torpedo launchers (often forward and aft) that define arcs of fire. Some designs integrate other functions into the launcher structure, and the launcher itself becomes a tactical focal point—damaged tubes, jammed doors, or destroyed launchers change what a ship can do in a fight.

For Tec‑Trek, the launcher hardware is part of the weapons ecosystem, but the torpedo entry focuses on the munition and how it’s used.
Sections.Modification culture: Photon torpedoes are among the franchise’s most frequently modified tools: tracking modifications, alternate warheads, and mission‑specific payloads show up repeatedly. That flexibility is part of why they remain in service even as newer torpedo types arrive.
Sections.Relationship to earlier torpedoes: In the 22nd century, Earth Starfleet relied on spatial torpedoes and later upgraded to photonic torpedoes, which are described as precursors to photon torpedoes. That makes the ‘photon’ family a through‑line from NX‑era development to later standard fleet armament.

Technologies.Name: Quantum Torpedoes
Technologies.Summary:
Quantum torpedoes are an advanced torpedo type used as a high-yield complement or successor to photons on certain late‑24th/25th‑century platforms. They’re framed as premium ordnance—more expensive, but worth it when you need a heavier punch.

On-screen, they appear as a recognizable ‘next step’ in Federation torpedo development, with a distinct visual language and recurring tactical reputation.

Sections.What they are: Quantum torpedoes are presented as a distinct class of tactical torpedo, used alongside or in place of photons. They use casings similar to photon-family torpedoes, but are differentiated by warhead type and performance.
Sections.Warhead and performance framing: Dialogue and technical references treat quantum torpedoes as higher-end ordnance—deployed when the target or situation demands more than standard photons. They’re often associated with newer ships and high-threat missions.
Sections.Deployment and platforms: Quantum torpedoes show up as part of the armament for specific Federation ships and installations during the late 24th century, with the Defiant frequently associated with their introduction. That context matters for Tec‑Trek: quantum torpedoes don’t replace photons everywhere; they’re a selective upgrade.
Sections.Operational similarities to photons: Despite the differences, quantum torpedoes are still torpedoes: finite ammunition, launch tubes, arming sequences, yield considerations, and guidance/lock issues. From a UI standpoint, you can reuse many of the same supporting concepts (launcher hardware, loading, arming, and countermeasures) while keeping the entry focused on what makes them distinct.

Technologies.Name: Spatial Torpedoes
Technologies.Summary:
Spatial torpedoes are 22nd‑century torpedo weapons carried aboard early Starfleet ships, including Enterprise NX‑01. Before NX‑era upgrades (phase cannons and later photonic torpedoes), spatial torpedoes were the most powerful weapons in the standard NX inventory.

They’re depicted as slower, shorter‑ranged, and less effective against deflector shields than later torpedo families—important context for why NX ships lean hard on careful tactics.

Sections.How they behave: Spatial torpedoes are portrayed more like early guided missiles than the later ‘energy-bright’ torpedo family: sublight launch, slower approach, and a higher chance of being intercepted or deflected. Against shields they can sometimes bounce and detonate without delivering decisive damage.
Sections.Range, speed, and shield interaction: Technical descriptions highlight a much shorter effective range compared with later photonic torpedoes, and show that point-defense fire can sometimes destroy them before impact. These weaknesses shape early NX-era combat scenes: closing distance is risky, and misses are expensive.
Sections.Loading and handling: Spatial torpedoes are shown as stored and handled as physical rounds, with loading involving manual steps—pulling a torpedo from storage racks and feeding it to a launching rail and tube. This reinforces that NX‑era weapons are closer to ‘early space navy’ hardware than later century automation.
Sections.NX‑01 layout: Enterprise NX‑01 is described as being able to launch spatial torpedoes from multiple points on the ship, including forward and aft tubes. Even after NX‑01 receives newer torpedoes, it keeps its spatial torpedo complement, which makes them a persistent part of NX operational capability.

Appearances.Notes: Spatial torpedoes described as the most powerful weapons prior to later upgrades.

Variants.Name: Standard spatial torpedo
Variants.Summary: Baseline NX-era torpedo with fixed yield and sublight missile-like behavior.

KeyTerms.Definition: A munition that travels at high sublight speeds rather than sustaining warp flight.
Defensive fire capable of intercepting incoming torpedoes before impact.

Constraints: Shorter range and slower speed than later torpedo families.
Reduced effectiveness against strong deflector shields; can be intercepted by point-defense fire.
Fixed yield (not easily tuned) in the NX-era depictions.
